tutorial.title: Exploring Event Properties
tutorial.descriptionContent: Explore event properties and create interactive webpages.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's take a look at other webpage events, like this one which triggers when we type in an input element.

lessons.title: Other elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can add events to other element types. For example, we can add onclick to a div element.

Make sure to pick onclick.

lessons.title: Dblclick
lessons.interactiveContent:
Depending on how we want the element to behave, we might want to add a different event.

For example, tapping an item to change its color makes more sense to happen on a double click. Code ondblclick.

Make sure to pick ondblclick.

lessons.title: Onscroll
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to trigger an event when a user scrolls on a webpage, we can use the onscroll property.

Complete the code and scroll down to change the background color.

Make sure to pick onscroll.

lessons.title: Onchange
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to trigger an event when an input field changes its value, we can use the onchange property.

This property only triggers after the change is done.

Make sure to pick onchange.

lessons.title: Oninput
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to trigger an event anytime an element's input changes, we use the oninput property.

Complete the code and type something in the input to see the code function.

Make sure to type oninput.

lessons.title: Question: Other elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
What elements can we add events to?

We can add events to any HTML elementWe can only add events to buttons

We can add events to any HTML element.

lessons.title: Question: Dblclick
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with the last line of this code?

It should be ondblclickIt should be changeColor()

It should be ondblclick.

lessons.title: Question: Onscroll
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

It should be textArea.onscrollIt should be textArea.onscroll()

It should be textArea.onscroll.

lessons.title: Question: Onchange
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code do?

Displays changes to the input element only after the changes are doneDisplays changes to the input element while they're taking place

Displays changes to the input element only after the changes are done.

lessons.title: Question: Oninput
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code do?

Displays changes to the input element only after the user exits the input fieldDisplays changes to the input element while the user is typing

Displays changes to the input element while the user is typing.

lessons.title: Example: Other elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a click event to the div element.

Make sure to pick onclick.

lessons.title: Example: Dblclick
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the changeColor() function trigger when the user double clicks.

Make sure to pick ondblclick.

lessons.title: Example: Onscroll
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the textArea element turn to red when scrolled.

Make sure to pick textArea, followed by onscroll.

lessons.title: Example: Onchange
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the onchange property to display the change to the input element only after the input is complete.

Make sure to pick onchange.

lessons.title: Example: Oninput
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the oninput property to display the input change while it takes place.

Make sure to type oninput.
